awd_titl_txt: Evolution of Contact Shear Resistance and Arching in Silica Sand
awd_abstract_narration:
The time-dependent behavior of granular geomaterials is among the least understood of their characteristics, and arching in granular materials is an elusive phenomenon without the definitive mathematical framework needed for engineering analyses. This research addresses time-dependent evolution of contacts between silica sand grains, with its consequences on strength, stiffness, and arching formation in sand. This study seeks to discover microscopic processes which govern the behavior of soils.  A link between evolution of inter-grain contacts and arching in granular geomaterials is sought, with a goal of a more informed use of arching in engineering analyses. The twofold purpose of the study is in promoting progress in science, and in benefits to society stemming from application of the research results in the development of national infrastructure. 

Behavior of soils is typically described by phenomenological models that predict their response to loads and load duration on the engineering scale. These models, however, do not explain the physical cause of the behavior they describe. In order to exercise any influence over the material behavior, the origin of the behavior needs to be discovered. This research addresses the fundamental question of why silica sand contacts exhibit time-dependent behavior that leads to time-dependent evolution of contact shear resistance and stiffness. A new generation of grain-scale testing apparatus will be constructed to test grain contacts subjected to complex loads. Testing of contacts will give rise to a mathematical description of contact behavior, which, subsequently, will be upscaled to the networks of grain contacts, and to the engineering scale behavior. The influence of the evolution process of material properties that originates at inter-grain contacts on formation of internal arches in soil masses will be studied. Both the distinct element approach and finite element analysis will be carried out to gain insight into the elusive phenomenon of arching in granular materials. The outcomes of the research will be illustrated with engineering applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Time-dependent behavior of sand, often referred to as aging, and the development of the arching effect in sand under sustained loads have puzzled the physics and engineering communities for decades. Both phenomena have an impact on the behavior of infrastructure founded in soils. The research focused on the mechanism of inter-grain contact behavior as the building block of the behavior of grain assemblies. This behavior was termed contact maturing, a process caused by sub-critical fracturing of inter-grain contact asperities resulting in an increase of contact stiffness, which, in turn, propagates through the spatial scale causing an increase in the stiffness of grain assemblies of silica sand deposits. This hypothesis allows one to explain the puzzling effects of soil maturing, and to account for this effect for better design of constructed infrastructure. In view of the evidence gained from testing sand grain assemblies, the settlement of sand deposits can be interpreted as a sequence of discrete instabilities, each contributing a minute grain displacement. Experimental evidence was collected from tests on individual grains and on grain assemblies, using custom-designed lab apparatus. The hypothesis permits explanation of, for example, the time-dependent increase in bearing capacity of piles, and it is likely to aid in development of a method which will allow quantitative predictions for civil infrastructure design.  

The study of the arching effect in soils was carried out using predominantly theoretical and numerical tools. Arching is an elusive phenomenon, often interpreted as the formation of arch-shape features with elevated stress. A problem of embankments on soft soils supported by a pile foundation system was considered. Numerical simulations of the stress field revealed major principal stresses aligned in an arch form, but no stress concentration was detected. However, the study revealed that the arching effect took place, which was strongly manifested in a disproportionately large load transferred to the piles, assuring large efficacy of the foundation system. Consequently, it became evident that formation of arches in the stress field is not necessary for the arching effect to take place. Indeed, using limit analysis, realistic bounds to the true foundation efficacy were found without using any arch-like features in the stress field or in the plastic kinematic field.

The scientific merit of this research is in the creative and original concepts exploiting a multi-scale approach to explaining the source of the time effects in silica sand as well as the arching effect in granular geomaterials.
